abstract: Ann Crittenden reports on international economic affairs for The New York Times.   Imagine Manhattan's Helmsley Palace in the South Bronx. Dacca's first new hotel since the 1960's is a gigantic five-star refuge, a $40 million product of Japanese aid to Bangladesh, set in the middle of one of the worst slums in the world. The Sonargaon is an elegant stage setting for local arts, and a retreat where visiting dignitaries, foreign-aid bureaucrats and journalists can relax over imported wines and Chateaubriand. But permeating the luxurious grounds and drifting over the swimming pool is a faint smell of garbage, of smoke fires and human waste. There is an extra edge of obsequiousness in the service, an unnerving desperation in the rickshaw drivers who crowd around the guests as they step into the capital city's street. No matter how insulated, life at the Sonargaon, like life everywhere in Bangladesh, is more or less uncomfortable.  Ever since winning its independence from Pakistan in a brutal civil war 10 years ago, Bangladesh has been the world's pre-eminent recipient of international aid. The country, no bigger than Illinois but with a population of 90 million - more than the United Kingdom, the Benelux countries and Switzerland combined - has been the beneficiary of a steady, multibillion-dollar dole of food and money from governments and private relief agencies from dozens of nations.  The money accounts for almost 90 percent of Bangladesh's development budget and roughly one-tenth of its annual gross national product.
lead_paragraph: Ann Crittenden reports on international economic affairs for The New York Times.

headline.main: FOREIGN AID UNDER FIRE
headline.print_headline: FOREIGN AID UNDER FIRE

byline.original: By Ann Crittenden

abstract: A student-led movement has called for a new confrontation with the Indian Government in its campaign for the expulsion from Assam, a northeastern state, of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants.   With another round of negotiations failing to make any headway, student leaders set Thursday, Dec. 2, for a 24-hour general strike and also called for the picketing of state government offices here in Gauhati, the capital of Assam. The Assamese here, who are primarily Hindu, are worried that they might be overwhelmed culturally and economically by the influx of immigrants, most of them Moslems from neighboring Bangladesh.   The state government, consisting since last March of administrators named by New Delhi, has reacted to the strike call by arresting two leading members of the All-Assam Student Union. Paramilitary and police forces have been placed on alert, and they have been ordered to make preventive detentions to keep order.
lead_paragraph: A student-led movement has called for a new confrontation with the Indian Government in its campaign for the expulsion from Assam, a northeastern state, of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants.

headline.main: INDIA'S ASSAM CALDRON BUBBLES DANGEROUSLY AGAIN
headline.print_headline: INDIA'S ASSAM CALDRON BUBBLES DANGEROUSLY AGAIN

byline.original: By Sanjoy Hazarika, Special To the New York Times

abstract: In a sweeping move, the Government of Bangladesh recently ordered multinational drug manufacturers to halt distribution of 1,742 drugs during the next nine months. Two hundred and thirty-seven of these drugs, including some produced by American companies, were immediately banned, apparently in response to similar bans or restrictions in industrialized countries.   The Bangladesh law primarily creates trade barriers intended to stimulate development of the local pharmaceutical industry. But the Ministry of Health also outlawed dangerous drugs like clioquinol, an anti-diarrhea drug that Japan banned years ago following evidence of severe neurological side-effects. American companies subsequently withdrew the drug from the United States market voluntarily, but continued selling it abroad in developing countries.
lead_paragraph: In a sweeping move, the Government of Bangladesh recently ordered multinational drug manufacturers to halt distribution of 1,742 drugs during the next nine months. Two hundred and thirty-seven of these drugs, including some produced by American companies, were immediately banned, apparently in response to similar bans or restrictions in industrialized countries.

headline.main: PRODUCTS UNSAFE AT HOME ARE STILL UNLOADED ABROAD
headline.print_headline: PRODUCTS UNSAFE AT HOME ARE STILL UNLOADED ABROAD

byline.original: By Michael Decourcy Hinds

abstract: In its 11 years as a nation, Bangladesh has had two political strongmen and many who wanted to be. The latest contender, Lieut.  Gen. H. M. Ershad, the army chief of staff, seized power last week, deposing an elected civilian President, Abdus Sattar.   Sounding like coup leaders usually sound, he claimed to have no personal political ambitions, said he had acted to root out corruption and stem economic decline and promised elections ''as soon as possible.'' In the meantime, his regime declared martial law and arrested several hundred people. Yesterday, he appointed Ahsanuddin Chowdhury, a retired judge, as a figurehead President.
lead_paragraph: In its 11 years as a nation, Bangladesh has had two political strongmen and many who wanted to be. The latest contender, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the army chief of staff, seized power last week, deposing an elected civilian President, Abdus Sattar.

headline.main: The World in Summary; General Steps In In Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: The World in Summary; General Steps In In Bangladesh

byline.original: By Milt Freudenheim and Barbara Slavin

abstract: The Reagan Administration, while keeping the situation in Bangladesh ''under review,'' is conducting normal relations with the martial-law Government of Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad, who seized power last Wednesday.   The United States Ambassador, Jane A. Coon, was present Saturday at the swearing-in of Bangladesh's new, ceremonial President, A.F.M.  Ahsanuddin Choudhury. This was a diplomatic signal, according to officials here, that the United States has no problems dealing with General Ershad, who took over in a nonviolent and not unexpected coup. Officials here called the takeover peaceful.
lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration, while keeping the situation in Bangladesh ''under review,'' is conducting normal relations with the martial-law Government of Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad, who seized power last Wednesday.

headline.main: IT SEES NO PROBLEM OVER THE COUP
headline.print_headline: U.S. GIVES SIGNAL TO BANGLADESH; IT SEES NO PROBLEM OVER THE COUP

byline.original: By Barbara Crossette, Special To the New York Times

abstract: The new martial-law administration of Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad appears to have been accepted here, if only provisionally.   The main question being asked by business leaders and foreign diplomats here is whether General Ershad can effectively deal with the high-level corruption that he has criticized. Beyond that, General Ershad's future may depend most on the price of jute.   Last Wednesday, General Ershad suspended all the political institutions under which Bangladesh had been governed for the last several years, first under Gen. Ziaur Rahman and, after General Zia's assassination last May, under his successor in the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, Abdus Sattar, a former jurist who was sworn in as President last November.
lead_paragraph: The new martial-law administration of Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad appears to have been accepted here, if only provisionally.

headline.main: News Analysis
headline.kicker: BANGLADESH PICTURE: NEW LEADER, SAME PROBLEMS
headline.print_headline: BANGLADESH PICTURE: NEW LEADER, SAME PROBLEMS; News Analysis

byline.original: By Colin Campbell, Special To the New York Times

abstract: Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, this nation's new military ruler, said in an interview today that he believed the Soviet Union was ''very dangerous.''   He also said that Bangladesh felt nothing but friendship toward the United States and that he thought President Reagan was a strong leader.   General Ershad also confirmed reports that two Soviet Embassy attaches were arrested a week ago while trying, for thus far unexplained reasons, to set fire to nearly 600 reels of movie film. Firm on Rooting Out Corruption   In the 75-minute interview, the soft-spoken general, who on March 24 suspended constitutional government, also made the following points:   - Not even family ties with army officers will save the lives of former Cabinet ministers if they are found guilty by military tribunals of corruption. ''We can hang them,'' General Ershad said.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, this nation's new military ruler, said in an interview today that he believed the Soviet Union was ''very dangerous.''

headline.main: BANGLADESH MILITARY LEADER SAYS HE FEARS SOVIET
headline.print_headline: BANGLADESH MILITARY LEADER SAYS HE FEARS SOVIET

byline.original: By Colin Campbell, Special To the New York Times

abstract: The nation's new military ruler announced today that special courts would be set up to punish all guilty of corruption, with the power to impose heavy prison terms or even the death penalty.   Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, the army chief of staff, who seized power Wednesday to ''end corruption in public life,'' issued martial-law regulations that said those facing prosecution could include former presidents, former Government ministers and members of the defense and police forces.   There were reports of many arrests, and several former Cabinet members were said to have been imprisoned for trial, but apparently none from the Government that was ousted in the coup.   The deposed President, 75-year-old Abdus Sattar, was said to be at his home here in Dacca, with police guards posted outside. Some reports said they were there for his protection; others said he was under house arrest.
lead_paragraph: The nation's new military ruler announced today that special courts would be set up to punish all guilty of corruption, with the power to impose heavy prison terms or even the death penalty.

headline.main: BANGLADESH GENERAL, CITING 'CORRUPTION' MAY TRY EX-LEADERS
headline.print_headline: BANGLADESH GENERAL, CITING 'CORRUPTION' MAY TRY EX-LEADERS

byline.original: By Colin Campbell, Special To the New York Times

abstract: Since World War II, the United States has been the world's bulwark against famine. In the eyes of many foreigners, and in those of many Americans, this has made up for the shortcomings they have seen and see in our foreign policy. But now we have turned our back on America's humane values and on the poorest of our neighbors. Engulfed in a wave of Social Darwinism, America devotes only 0.27 percent of its gross national product to food and development aid in comparison to France's 0.62 percent, West Germany's 0.43 percent, Canada's 0.42 percent, and Britain's 0.34 percent.   The United States is still especially qualified to take the lead in agricultural-aid and development programs. We invented land-grant colleges, agricultural extension services, and rural credit. We are foremost in agricultural research, have the world's most efficient farmers, and export by far the largest amount of food.
lead_paragraph: Since World War II, the United States has been the world's bulwark against famine. In the eyes of many foreigners, and in those of many Americans, this has made up for the shortcomings they have seen and see in our foreign policy. But now we have turned our back on America's humane values and on the poorest of our neighbors. Engulfed in a wave of Social Darwinism, America devotes only 0.27 percent of its gross national product to food and development aid in comparison to France's 0.62 percent, West Germany's 0.43 percent, Canada's 0.42 percent, and Britain's 0.34 percent.

headline.main: by Jean Mayer
headline.print_headline: FEEDING THE WORLD; by Jean Mayer

abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ordered emergency shipments of water, food and money today to as many as 100 million people stricken by drought in isolated villages across India, Government officials said.   Mrs. Gandhi ordered relief officials to use all available equipment to reach thousands of isolated villages in 10 of India's 21 states where insufficient monsoon rains have left wells dry and farmland parched.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ordered emergency shipments of water, food and money today to as many as 100 million people stricken by drought in isolated villages across India, Government officials said.

headline.main: Relief Supplies Ordered In Vast Drought in India
headline.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Relief Supplies Ordered In Vast Drought in India

byline.original: UPI

abstract: Malthusian prophecies of population growth and consumption rates overwhelming the environment are alive and disconcertingly well.  The United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, meeting in Bangkok last week, traced much of the region's environmental damage to high birth rates and poverty.
lead_paragraph: Malthusian prophecies of population growth and consumption rates overwhelming the environment are alive and disconcertingly well. The United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, meeting in Bangkok last week, traced much of the region's environmental damage to high birth rates and poverty.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Too Little, Too Many
headline.print_headline: Ideas & Trends; Too Little, Too Many

byline.original: By Eva Hoffman and Margot Slade

abstract: HEADBIRTHS OR THE GERMANS ARE DYING OUT By Gunter Grass.Translated by Ralph Manheim.  A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book.136 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95.   ZEUS, you will remember, had the first ''headbirth,'' springing Athene. It is, says Gunter Grass, ''a paradox that has impregnated male minds to this day.'' It is also a parable of art. Grass Zeusifies. His own ''Headbirths'' - part fiction, part travelogue, part screenplay and part political pamphlet - is a wise, sad, witty mess.   (The bad boy of German letters has more structural problems with his short books than with his long ones, as if he felt that such baggy monsters as ''The Tin Drum,'' ''Dog Years'' and ''The Flounder'' needed elaborate skeletons, whereas ''Cat and Mouse'' and ''The Meeting at Telgte,'' so skinny, could be spineless.)
lead_paragraph: HEADBIRTHS OR THE GERMANS ARE DYING OUT By Gunter Grass.Translated by Ralph Manheim. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book.136 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95.

headline.main: CONSIDER A BILLION GERMANS
headline.print_headline: CONSIDER A BILLION GERMANS

byline.original: By John Leonard

abstract: The second annual World Food Day, sponsored by the Department of Agriculture, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and 262 private voluntary organizations, was observed today in 150 countries.   The F.A.O. estimates that as many as 400 million to 500 million people suffer from poverty-induced malnutrition, particularly in the third world.   The idea of a World Food Day originated in 1979, when the F.A.O.  decided to designate a day each year to focus international attention on food-related cncernss. Oct. 16, the date of the founding of that organization in 1945, was selected.
lead_paragraph: The second annual World Food Day, sponsored by the Department of Agriculture, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and 262 private voluntary organizations, was observed today in 150 countries.

headline.main: 150 NATIONS MARKING SECOND WORLD FOOD DAY
headline.print_headline: 150 NATIONS MARKING SECOND WORLD FOOD DAY

abstract: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's Last of nine articles that have appeared periodically since Sept. 27. By DENA KLEIMAN   They live across the hall from one another - two couples who could not have less in common. One grew up in Brooklyn, the other on the outskirts of Saigon. And yet they have had a powerful impact on each other's lives by sharing what they know best.   Miriam and Bernard Roiss used to pride themselves on their recipes for Hungarian goulash and kidney pie. Now they stock rice wrappers in their refrigerator and eat most of their meals with chopsticks.
lead_paragraph: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's Last of nine articles that have appeared periodically since Sept. 27. By DENA KLEIMAN

headline.main: New York Times Magazine June 6, 1982
headline.print_headline: New York Times Magazine June 6, 1982

abstract: WHEN Mona Doyle, a marketing pollster, asks people if they want alternatives to the chemical preservatives in their food, most of them say yes. When she asks if they want fruits, vegetables and meat that stay fresher longer, they say yes.   But when she mentions a preservation technique that promises to make those things possible, they respond, she says, by asking such half-serious questions as ''Does it make you glow in the dark?''   The technique is irradiation - exposing foods to gamma rays or electrons emitted by radioactive materials - and it may soon do to some consumer foods in this country what it has long done to cosmetics, hospital equipment, baby powders and meals astronauts have eaten on the moon and in orbit: kill off substantial amounts of bacteria in food or sterilize it altogether. The food itself does not become radioactive, just as dental and chest X-rays do not make teeth and lungs radioactive. In low doses, irradiation has little effect on taste.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Mona Doyle, a marketing pollster, asks people if they want alternatives to the chemical preservatives in their food, most of them say yes. When she asks if they want fruits, vegetables and meat that stay fresher longer, they say yes.

headline.main: IRRADIATED FOOD: PROMISE AND CONTROVERSY
headline.print_headline: IRRADIATED FOOD: PROMISE AND CONTROVERSY

byline.original: By James P. Sterba

abstract: Israel has given United States intelligence officials documents and other information obtained in Lebanon indicating that mercenaries from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and various African nations were fighting with the Palestine Liberation Organization.   At the same time, the Israelis also gave American officials an account of what they considered the surprisingly large stores of weapons seized by Israeli troops in Lebanon. Among those weapons, the Israelis said, were American M-16 rifles that had been sold to Saudi Arabia.   Copies of the documents, most of which were given to President Reagan late last month by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, were made available here by Israeli officials.
lead_paragraph: Israel has given United States intelligence officials documents and other information obtained in Lebanon indicating that mercenaries from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and various African nations were fighting with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline.main: ISRAELIS CHARGE PALESTINIAN USE OF MERCENARIES
headline.print_headline: ISRAELIS CHARGE PALESTINIAN USE OF MERCENARIES

byline.original: By Bernard Weinraub, Special To the New York Times

abstract: In private, many Arab diplomats here acknowledge that they have painted themselves into a corner by demanding Israel's expulsion from the current session of the General Assembly.  These envoys say they want a face-saving escape from the decision of the Arab League members here at a closed-door meeting last week, although only Mahmoud Aboul-Nasr of Oman will say this in public.   On Tuesday, the members of the larger Islamic Conference Organization, particularly Pakistan, offered what appeared to be a plausible way out: instead of challenging Israel on the Assembly floor, the Arabs would sign a letter expressing reservations over Israel's credentials in view of its ''flagrant violations'' of international law and United Nations resolutions. But such meetings operate under what they call a rule of consensus, meaning unanimity.  Libya said no, and that blocked that exit.
lead_paragraph: In private, many Arab diplomats here acknowledge that they have painted themselves into a corner by demanding Israel's expulsion from the current session of the General Assembly. These envoys say they want a face-saving escape from the decision of the Arab League members here at a closed-door meeting last week, although only Mahmoud Aboul-Nasr of Oman will say this in public.

headline.main: News Analysis
headline.kicker: ARABS AT U.N. FACE CHOICE: LOGIC OR PASSION
headline.print_headline: ARABS AT U.N. FACE CHOICE: LOGIC OR PASSION; News Analysis

byline.original: By Bernard D. Nossiter, Special To the New York Times

abstract: The chief of South Africa's military intelligence agency and three other ranking South African officers held a series of unannounced meetings with officials here last week to plan how the United Nations would monitor a cease-fire leading to independence in South-West Africa.   Both sides said today that the talks went well, although neither the South African Government nor its guerrilla opponents have yet made the critical decision to halt the fighting in the former German colony, which is also known as Namibia.   But in the eyes of some diplomats here, the most remarkable feature of the meetings was that they took place at all, since the United Nations is on record as loathing the South African Government and its apartheid system.   The talks, which began Aug. 2, took place over three days in the map room on the 38th floor of United Nations headquarters.
lead_paragraph: The chief of South Africa's military intelligence agency and three other ranking South African officers held a series of unannounced meetings with officials here last week to plan how the United Nations would monitor a cease-fire leading to independence in South-West Africa.

headline.main: SOUTH AFRICAN OFFICERS CONFER ON NAMIBIA AT THE U.N.
headline.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICAN OFFICERS CONFER ON NAMIBIA AT THE U.N.

byline.original: By Bernard D. Nossiter, Special To the New York Times

abstract: HOLIDAY   New York has a special facility for taking on the coloration of whatever holidays its people are celebrating. Today is St. Patrick's Day, and the spirit will suffuse the city with more than the parade that has become its local cliche.   In quieter precincts, just a few steps away from the Fifth Avenue parade, an exhibition of vintage photographs depicting Dublin between 1880 and 1914 opens today. It is in the Rotunda, on the third floor, at the entrance of the main reference room of the New York Public Library's main building at 42d Street (930-0717).   The hundred views seen here were taken by Robert French for a picture postcard company and are among the trove of 40,000 glassplate negatives found by Kieran Hickey, a film maker, in Dublin's National Library. The exhibition, courtesy of the Irish Foreign Ministry, has been given the name ''Fadographs of a Yestern Scene,'' taking its words from the vocabulary of that famous Dubliner of that period, James Joyce.
lead_paragraph: HOLIDAY

headline.main: GOING OUT GUIDE
headline.print_headline: GOING OUT GUIDE

abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi offered today to sign a friendship treaty with Pakistan and pledged that India would never attack its neighbor.   Speaking to Pakistani journalists, Mrs. Gandhi said: ''Our treaty with the Soviet Union is just what it says. It is a friendship treaty. We are willing to have a friendship treaty with you.''
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi offered today to sign a friendship treaty with Pakistan and pledged that India would never attack its neighbor.

headline.main: MRS. GANDHI OFFERS TO SIGN PAKISTAN PACT
headline.print_headline: MRS. GANDHI OFFERS TO SIGN PAKISTAN PACT

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

abstract: SEASONAL   Today is Ash Wednesday, and the St. Bart's Players, for the first time, will usher it in with a musical at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 51st Street. The musical, ''Godspell,'' is as old as the New Testament in its theme, which is based on the Gospel according to St. Matthew. But it is only middle-aged as theater, having blossomed on Off Broadway in 1971, with an ensuing run of more than 2,100 performances.   The show is by Stephen Schwartz, composer and lyricist, and Michael Tebelak, adapter of the work. In this Lenten production, it is directed by Susan H. Schulman, who last year did a remarkably lively revival of ''Annie Get Your Gun'' at the Equity Library Theater. Phil Hall and Steven Gelfer serve as musical director and choreographer.
lead_paragraph: SEASONAL

headline.main: GOING OUT GUIDE
headline.print_headline: GOING OUT GUIDE

abstract: IS life on the earth getting better and better, with the promise of ample supplies of food, energy, income and health care for all? Or is the world headed for an ecological and social disaster, overcrowded, choked on pollution and running out of natural resources?   The debate between optimists and pessimists on these questions has intensified over the last year and a half in the wake of ''The Global 2000 Report to the President,'' a major Carter Administration study that found alarming stresses on the earth's resources and environment. Last week, at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington, the combatants again took verbal swipes at each other.   It became apparent that much of the gloom-and-doom rhetoric of recent years has been based on questionable data and analyses. But the evidence to support an ''everything is rosy'' view is equally shaky.
lead_paragraph: IS life on the earth getting better and better, with the promise of ample supplies of food, energy, income and health care for all? Or is the world headed for an ecological and social disaster, overcrowded, choked on pollution and running out of natural resources?

headline.main: WILL THE NEXT 20 YEARS BRING PROSPERITY OR DECLINE?
headline.print_headline: WILL THE NEXT 20 YEARS BRING PROSPERITY OR DECLINE?

byline.original: By Philip M. Boffey

abstract: Guyana's long-stagnant economy has gone into a tailspin, pulling many of its citizens' living standard down with it.   The country is suffering from a problem common to the Caribbean region: lower income from its traditional exports - in this case, sugar, rice and bauxite - and sharply higher prices for petroleum products.   Some international economists believe that Guyana's economic situation has been complicated by problems in production and management. Still another factor, they say, has been the Government's effort to build a system of ''cooperative socialism'' while trading almost entirely within the capitalist world.
lead_paragraph: Guyana's long-stagnant economy has gone into a tailspin, pulling many of its citizens' living standard down with it.

headline.main: GUYANA'S ECONOMY IN A SEVERE CRISIS
headline.print_headline: GUYANA'S ECONOMY IN A SEVERE CRISIS

byline.original: By Richard J. Meislin, Special To the New York Times

abstract: International A crackdown in Guatemala one day after a coup surprised many people who had expected the new military leaders to form an interim government with civilian politicians and to set speedy elections. The junta of three senior military officers who seized power Tuesday suspended the Constitution and all political activities. (Page A1, Column 6.) Abuses by Salvadoran security forces appear to be diminishing a bit, but many of the traditional excesses are continuing. Much of the international opposition to the ruling junta arises from its general failure to curb the killing of noncombatants by security forces and the paramilitary death squads linked with them. (A1:4-5.)
lead_paragraph: International A crackdown in Guatemala one day after a coup surprised many people who had expected the new military leaders to form an interim government with civilian politicians and to set speedy elections. The junta of three senior military officers who seized power Tuesday suspended the Constitution and all political activities. (Page A1, Column 6.) Abuses by Salvadoran security forces appear to be diminishing a bit, but many of the traditional excesses are continuing. Much of the international opposition to the ruling junta arises from its general failure to curb the killing of noncombatants by security forces and the paramilitary death squads linked with them. (A1:4-5.)

headline.main: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 25, 1982
headline.print_headline: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 25, 1982

abstract: THE winged bean, a plant virtually unknown six years ago, has definitely taken off. It is now being grown in more than 70 countries. A thousand researchers in more than 60 countries receive The Winged Bean Flyer, a newsletter established to keep scientists abreast of the rapid developments concerning this seeingly miraculous plant. The highly nutritious crop promises to become the soybean of the tropics, where it alone may do more than any combination of foods to counter malnutrition.   ''Few crops have risen so quickly from total obscurity to the winged bean's current level of prominence,'' notes a new report from the National Academy of Sciences' National Research Council, which catapulted the winged bean to international fame among food researchers with its first report on the plant in 1975.   Among those who study it, the winged bean is known as ''a supermarket on a stalk'' because it combines the desirable characteristics of the green bean, garden pea, spinach, mushroom, soybean, bean sprout and potato. Save for the stalk, virtually the entire plant is fit for human consumption - from flowers and leaves to tuberous roots and seeds.
lead_paragraph: THE winged bean, a plant virtually unknown six years ago, has definitely taken off. It is now being grown in more than 70 countries. A thousand researchers in more than 60 countries receive The Winged Bean Flyer, a newsletter established to keep scientists abreast of the rapid developments concerning this seeingly miraculous plant. The highly nutritious crop promises to become the soybean of the tropics, where it alone may do more than any combination of foods to counter malnutrition.

headline.main: WINGED BEAN HAILED AS A POTENT WEAPON AGAINST MALNUTRITION
headline.print_headline: WINGED BEAN HAILED AS A POTENT WEAPON AGAINST MALNUTRITION

byline.original: By Jane E. Brody

abstract: He is ''charming,'' ''disciplined,'' ''urbane,'' ''correct,'' ''self-confident.'' This is how Western diplomats who have dealt with him for years describe Imre Hollai , the new Hungarian president of the General Assembly.  Talking about himself, however, he stresses his proletarian roots.   ''I was born in the second largest working-class district in Budapest,'' Mr. Hollai began in a recent conversation in a suite at the Beekman Towers Hotel, where he and his wife will spend the next three months. His father worked in a tannery; young Imre was a mechanic in a lamp factory during the war.
lead_paragraph: He is ''charming,'' ''disciplined,'' ''urbane,'' ''correct,'' ''self-confident.'' This is how Western diplomats who have dealt with him for years describe Imre Hollai , the new Hungarian president of the General Assembly. Talking about himself, however, he stresses his proletarian roots.

headline.main: A PROLETARIAN AT U.N. HELM
headline.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; A PROLETARIAN AT U.N. HELM

byline.original: By Bernard D. Nossiter, Special To the New York Times

abstract: An international relief worker visiting Vietnam last spring noticed a cartoon in a Hanoi newspaper, illustrating the attitudes of farmers ''before'' and ''after'' the Government reforms that gave farmers more incentives to produce. In the first drawing, a peasant with a cigarette dangling from his mouth is lolling behind a buffalo plowing the fields. In the second it is night, and the peasant is racing behind the buffalo with a lantern.   The point implicit in the cartoons and the truth that Vietnam may be reluctantly grasping is that large-scale, factory-style agriculture, whether communist or capitalist in organization, is simply not as efficient as tilling the land by and for the benefit of the individual farmer.
lead_paragraph: An international relief worker visiting Vietnam last spring noticed a cartoon in a Hanoi newspaper, illustrating the attitudes of farmers ''before'' and ''after'' the Government reforms that gave farmers more incentives to produce. In the first drawing, a peasant with a cigarette dangling from his mouth is lolling behind a buffalo plowing the fields. In the second it is night, and the peasant is racing behind the buffalo with a lantern.

headline.main: SMALLER IS BETTER AND PRIVATE BEST FOR FARMING
headline.print_headline: SMALLER IS BETTER AND PRIVATE BEST FOR FARMING

byline.original: By Ann Crittenden

abstract: The lives of 20,000 children could be saved each day by adoption of four simple, low-cost health measures that have already proved successful in limited trials in several developing countries, the United Nations Children's Fund said in a report yesterday.   Although health problems among the world's poor children remain enormous and may never be eliminated, fund officials said a significant impact could now be made with existing techniques that could be easily used even by illiterate people who have few hygienic amenities.   Dr. Richard Jolly, deputy director for programs, said at a news conference that if the four measures were ''seriously implemented, half the young children who now die each year would live.'' He added, ''Doubts and skepticism need to be overcome, rather than vested interests.''
lead_paragraph: The lives of 20,000 children could be saved each day by adoption of four simple, low-cost health measures that have already proved successful in limited trials in several developing countries, the United Nations Children's Fund said in a report yesterday.

headline.main: UNICEF URGES FOUR STEPS TO SAVE CHILDREN'S LIVES
headline.print_headline: UNICEF URGES FOUR STEPS TO SAVE CHILDREN'S LIVES

byline.original: By Jane E. Brody

abstract: The recession in the industrialized nations has translated into increased economic hardship and new political tensions across much of Asia, Africa and Latin America.   Last year, for example, the economies of the developing world grew by an average of just six-tenths of 1 percent and, with population growth racing ahead, per capita income fell for the first time in 20 years. This year the figures are even worse.   ''Zero growth in a country like Sweden is hardly a disaster,'' one United Nations development economist said, ''but in the third world it means condemnation to perpetual poverty.'' In Role of a Spectator   In addition, more than at any time since World War II, the industrial powers are obsessed by their own problems and are mostly deaf to the cries for help from the poorer nations of the Southern Hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: The recession in the industrialized nations has translated into increased economic hardship and new political tensions across much of Asia, Africa and Latin America.

headline.main: Fourth article of a series appearing periodically on current world economic problems.
headline.kicker: ECONOMIC FRUSTRATION GRIPS MANY DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
headline.print_headline: ECONOMIC FRUSTRATION GRIPS MANY DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; Fourth article of a series appearing periodically on current world economic problems.

byline.original: By Alan Riding, Special To the New York Times

abstract: In a spare, sunlit room the man sits, doing work men like him have done for thousands of years. Outside the city streets are grimy, spotted with trash. The building in which the man sits looks like a hundred other modern buildings, built of brick and glass in square lines, with that odd sense of impermanence typical of the second half of the 20th century.   Inside, Eliezer Posen is writing a Torah. He hunches over a simple desk, with ink and tools and a copy of the text ranged around him. He speaks each word aloud, and writes it in small elaborate black characters that shine in the sun.
lead_paragraph: In a spare, sunlit room the man sits, doing work men like him have done for thousands of years. Outside the city streets are grimy, spotted with trash. The building in which the man sits looks like a hundred other modern buildings, built of brick and glass in square lines, with that odd sense of impermanence typical of the second half of the 20th century.

headline.main: AN ANCIENT AND MOST EXACTING CRAFT
headline.print_headline: ABOUT NEW YORK; AN ANCIENT AND MOST EXACTING CRAFT

byline.original: By Anna Quindlen

abstract: Time was, when diplomatic assignment to Washington was seen as something less than a coup. It was, some said, a sentence to perdition: a swampy, provincial capital where mosquitos and humidity reigned and the diplomat was entitled to hardship pay.   That has changed. A post here is now considered a plum and some of the best and the brightest of the diplomatic corps can be found here. And it is not the advent of air-conditioning alone that accounts for the change.
lead_paragraph: Time was, when diplomatic assignment to Washington was seen as something less than a coup. It was, some said, a sentence to perdition: a swampy, provincial capital where mosquitos and humidity reigned and the diplomat was entitled to hardship pay.

headline.main: WHERE THE ELITE CAN NOW MEET
headline.print_headline: EMBASSY ROW; WHERE THE ELITE CAN NOW MEET

byline.original: By Barbara Gamarekian, Special To the New York Times

abstract: Peter Townsend, a professor of social policy at England's University of Bristol, has become a key figure in discussions of social policy issues. His latest book, ''Poverty in the United Kingdom,'' proposes a ''deprivation index'' that, Mr. Townsend says, provides a scientific method for measuring poverty. The index is based on a dozen criteria that depart from traditional income-based standards and include such categories as taking yearly vacations and eating cooked meals.   The book has stimulated lively controversy, much of it revolving around the question of whether absolute (as opposed to relative) poverty can be measured. In recent months, Mr. Townsend has been consulted by the British Government and has commanded huge audiences for his lectures.   Steven Rattner, a New York Times correspondent in London, asked Mr. Townsend to elaborate on his ideas. Excerpts from their conversation follow.
lead_paragraph: Peter Townsend, a professor of social policy at England's University of Bristol, has become a key figure in discussions of social policy issues. His latest book, ''Poverty in the United Kingdom,'' proposes a ''deprivation index'' that, Mr. Townsend says, provides a scientific method for measuring poverty. The index is based on a dozen criteria that depart from traditional income-based standards and include such categories as taking yearly vacations and eating cooked meals.

headline.main: POVERTY IS MORE THAN BEING FLAT BROKE
headline.print_headline: POVERTY IS MORE THAN BEING FLAT BROKE

abstract: Israel's newly reopened gateway to Africa takes the form here of a modest suite of offices on the second floor of a high-rise building that, on its upper reaches, affords a vista of the Congo River, a stream that is no stranger to the attempted penetration of this continent by outsiders.   A century ago, Henry Morten Stanley, the Welsh-American journalist-turned-explorer-turned-colonialist passed this way and his journeyings took him clean across Africa.   Moshe Itan, Israel's sole representative and charge d'affaires at the recently opened embassy, says he hopes his country will have equal success in re-establishing its presence on a similar scale, now that President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has broken ranks with the bulk of the Africans and restored diplomatic relations. The blackruled nations severed ties with Israel in 1973 during the war that October between Israel and the Arabs.   Israel's invasion of Lebanon makes it likely, however, that elsewhere in Africa, Israel's diplomats will face as much of a struggle in raising their flag as did the early explorers.
lead_paragraph: Israel's newly reopened gateway to Africa takes the form here of a modest suite of offices on the second floor of a high-rise building that, on its upper reaches, affords a vista of the Congo River, a stream that is no stranger to the attempted penetration of this continent by outsiders.

headline.main: ISRAEL'S TOEHOLD IN AFRICA MAY FALL VICTIM TO WAR
headline.print_headline: ISRAEL'S TOEHOLD IN AFRICA MAY FALL VICTIM TO WAR

byline.original: By Alan Cowell, Special To the New York Times

abstract: OH WHAT A PARADISE IT SEEMS By John Cheever.  100 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10. By JOHN LEONARD   AMONG the living, John Cheever's favorite American writer is Saul Bellow. It is as if the apple wanted to be a lemon, and can't. ''Oh What a Paradise It Seems,'' a very short and often lovely novel, might just as easily have been a long letter from Cheever to Bellow on being old. But what would Bellow's Mr. Sammler make of Cheever's Lemuel Sears? They seem not to be visiting the same planet.   Lemuel - from the Hebrew: ''pledged'' or ''consecrated to God'' - forgives the planet in advance: ''Coming from a generation that could, perhaps, be characterized by the vastness of its disposition to complain, he didn't suppose he could scorn men and women who must be looking for something better. That things had been better was the music, the reprise for his days. It had been sung by his elders, by his associates, he had heard it sung in college by Toynbee and Spengler. ... What a bore it had been to live in this self-induced autumnal twilight!''
lead_paragraph: OH WHAT A PARADISE IT SEEMS By John Cheever. 100 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10. By JOHN LEONARD

headline.main: CHEEVER COUNTRY
headline.print_headline: CHEEVER COUNTRY

byline.original: By John Leonard

abstract: MOLLY IVINS is a native Texan and a columnist for The Dallas Times-Herald. By MOLLY IVINS   T exas is a wonderful, funny and astonishing place, but it helps if you do not suffer from excessively refined sensibilities. Texas can be tacky.   Texas, God forbid that anyone should forget it, is a big state. It has everything that anyplace with a claim to civilization has - symphony orchestras, museums, theaters, universities, fern bars, psychiatrists and Chinese restaurants. It also has more provincialism and chauvinism than any American place I know of. By keeping in mind that provincialism is a universal characteristic, the visitor will be able to summon the tolerance required for the Texas strain.
lead_paragraph: MOLLY IVINS is a native Texan and a columnist for The Dallas Times-Herald. By MOLLY IVINS

headline.main: GETTING IN TOUCH WITH TEXAS
headline.print_headline: GETTING IN TOUCH WITH TEXAS

abstract: RICHARD EDER is chief of The Times Paris bureau. By RICHARD EDER   ''G o with me,'' the classical guidebook commanded, calling itself, for that reason, ''vade mecum.'' Guidebooks emerged when grand tours began to go under: those arranged in lordly fashion, using servants and letters of introduction, and those carried out more rumbustiously -Dumas brawling through Andalusia, Borrow busybodying his way around what he chose to call ''Wild Wales.'' They gave place to the institutionalized timidity of the Victorians, who preferred books to introductions, as being more likely to unite a decent moral tone with thorough instruction. Hence Baedeker.   Guidebooks have since sprouted in every direction. The heirs to Baedeker flourish: Blue Guides and Nagel's guides, detailing village by village and mile after mile. They are soberly written and ostensibly without angles or color. Only ostensibly: The notion that the world has an intelligible history that has deposited artifacts that are worth seeing and, furthermore, ought to be seen, is colorful enough these days, if you think about it.
lead_paragraph: RICHARD EDER is chief of The Times Paris bureau. By RICHARD EDER

headline.main: GUIDEBOOKS TO ALMOST EVERYWHERE
